channel.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
channel.description:
On my 250gb HDD I had about 10GB of unallocated space from ages ago. This space had nothing on, it had been secure erased. I recently torrented Partition Magic, and so tried to go about turning the unallocated partition in to an NTFS format and then merging it with my Windows partition. Anyway, when I pressed apply to re-format the partition I got a BSoD with contained the following technical errors:
STOP: 0x000000CA (0x00000001, 0x899CE270, 0x89B12558, 0x00000000)
Now my problem is that when I get in to GRUB and go to Windows Professional XP SP2 it will give me the screen saying "Windows did not shut down correctly" and gives me the choice of safe mode, last known good config etc. I go on anyone of these and it will not get to the Windows loading screen as it seems to automatically restart. I then go to the advanced settings (F8) and try all of the options - none work.
I've tried booting up with the Windows disk - Gets to Setup is starting Windows and then goes straight to the BSoD. I've tried using ERD Commander to get back in to Windows - Straight to BSoD.
I'm fairly sure I will not be losing any truly important data, but there's a good 100GB of programmes, software, music, and video that I've collected over the past few years, which I would prefer not to lose.
Does anyone have any suggestions on what I can do to get Windows back running normally again? If not, how do I go about re-installing Windows - Seeing as I can't use the Windows disk.
I'm pretty stuck right now, and have no idea what to do from now on.
Any help much appreciated - willing to answer any Qs you may have.
PS - I can log on to Ubuntu and get to my WINDOWs files through there... I have tried using an external hd to transfer some data through Ubuntu, but as soon as I reconnected my external to my computer, it was unable to mount. Any ideas?

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You can install gparted in the ubuntu livecd (it may already be installed) and use it to format your drive. Or you can use a gparted livecd to do it.

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:9, topic:278358”]I personally use puppy linux for recovery (it comes with gparted)
Mr.Chris just try to move the files and if it screws up again reformat again! NTFS should work.

I just read over the post again and I realised that this problem could be a dying CMOS (BIOS) battery or a corrupt BIOS. I would try to use Fail-Safe Defaults on your BIOS and even replace the battery[/quote]

The computer is relatively new, and I wouldn’t think it would be related to the BIOS. I can reset it and it does boot up in the order set no problem. I will go through the BIOS again before I do anything else. thanks for the tips

The files are fine. I can read them in Ubuntu - I’m not sure what happened, but I will a transfer tomorrow. When my files are saved and secured, how would I go about reformatting my drive - noting I do not have access to Windows at all on this computer.

Thanks for all the help - I’ll see what I can do tomorrow. I better hit the hay as I have an English exam tomorrow

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:8, topic:278358”]I’m in Ubuntu now, and I can access everything in my Windows partition. Problem is, when I transfer the files to my external (which is a NTFS file system), it just seems to corrupt all the files and make them unreadable and undeletable. I then have to reformat my external. I rekon I am probably using the wrong file system to do this?

Edit - Managed to get my external to mount. It’s on a NTFS file system. Should I be able to simply transfer my data from my Windows Partition to my external through Ubuntu? Or is there something im missing…?[/quote]

An NTFS filesystem should be fine, are you sure the files on your hard drive aren’t corrupted already?

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I personally use puppy linux for recovery (it comes with gparted)
Mr.Chris just try to move the files and if it screws up again reformat again! NTFS should work.

I just read over the post again and I realised that this problem could be a dying CMOS (BIOS) battery or a corrupt BIOS. I would try to use Fail-Safe Defaults on your BIOS and even replace the battery

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

I’m in Ubuntu now, and I can access everything in my Windows partition. Problem is, when I transfer the files to my external (which is a NTFS file system), it just seems to corrupt all the files and make them unreadable and undeletable. I then have to reformat my external. I rekon I am probably using the wrong file system to do this?

Edit - Managed to get my external to mount. It’s on a NTFS file system. Should I be able to simply transfer my data from my Windows Partition to my external through Ubuntu? Or is there something im missing…?

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Partition Magic is shit, you should have gotten a free gparted live cd and used it.

Try recovering your data by booting into a linux livecd, mounting your windows partition and see if anything is there. I recommend kubuntu or xubuntu

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

I was formatting it not merging it, correct.

Fat Cookies - How would I be able to reformat everything? Can I do this through Ubuntu?

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I would forget about trying to get your current Windows working. Personally I would get a Linux Live CD to do the transferring of files to an external medium (Even DVDs). Then reformat everything (Including the MBR) and start again.
Maybe your “torrented” Partition Magic was a bit dodgy. I personally use a Linux Live CD when dealing with partitioning because nothing can get in the way and its definatly malware free.

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

OK, you were formatting the unallocated space when you got the BSoD right? It wasn’t when you were merging it with the Windows Partition, am I right?

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

Not sure if I can get to the recovery console. When I put in my windows disk, I can get to “Setup is starting Windows” and then it will jump straight to the BSoD.

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD

item.title: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Recovery Console

The Recovery Console is a feature of the Windows 2000, Windows XP and Windows Server 2003 operating systems. It provides the means for administrators to perform a limited range of tasks using a command line interface. Its primary function is to enable administrators to recover from situations where Windows does not boot as far as presenting its graphical user interface. The recovery console is used to provide a way to access the hard drive in an emergency through the command prompt. As such, the...

From there on do chkdsk and fixboot. Maybe?

Read full topic
item.source: Stupid Mistake - Messed up my HDD
